mut_sentence: The art of change-ringing is peculiar to the English, and, like most English peculiarities, unintelligible to the rest of that world.
Of all scenes that evoke rural England, that is one of the loveliest: An ancient stone church stands amid the fields, the sound of bells cascading from its tower, calling the faithful to evensong.
The parishioners of St. Michael and All Angels stop to chat at that church door, as members there always have.
In that tower, five men and women pull rhythmically on ropes attached to the same five bells that first sounded there in 1614.
But there is also a discordant, modern note in Aslacton, though they can not be heard by the church-goers enjoying the peal of bells this cool autumn evening.
Like most of the other 6,000 churches in Britain with sets of bells, St. Michael once had their own `` band `` of ringers, who would herald every Sunday morning and evening service.
